comment: I am not a fan of this one. Love the packaging and love seeing it beside BH, and BH Rye though. Dark cherry on the nose. A chalky cocoa and fruit taste. And a lingering old chocolate covered cherry on the finish. That "touch" of port is a touch too much in my opinion.
someone knew what they were doing...tastes like a Manhattan, but with a big nose

A real odd-ball--Basil Hayden's Dark Rye builds on the success of Aberta Premium Dark Horse (rebranded as Alberta Rye Dark Batch in the US) by flipping the formula. Where the original was mostly Canadian rye with a dollop of high rye bourbon and a splash of sherry, this fellow leads with an American rye and throws in a measure of Canadian rye and a splash of port. Okay, sure. A dark, almost ruby-ish colour. Nice--if light--nose: leads with red fruits (lots of berry), clove, vanilla, a tiny bit of Beam peanut funk, some baking spice and green herbs. Sourdough bread. Yeasty--it actually reminds me of the way my hometown smelled when the Hiram Walker distillery was in the process of fermenting. A little bit of ginger, some pickle juice. Gravel. Taste is light and again leads sweet--the red fruits from the port, followed by a bit of vanilla and butterscotch, and the spicy, herbacious rye coming through just a bit at the end. The finish is strangely sour and tangy: vinous, a whiff of vanilla, and then it's gone.  Aside from that finish, this whisky is nice enough (if maybe leaning a bit too sweet), but it's hamstrung by two fatal flaws: a super-low ABV (baseline 40% for, *sigh*, "smoothness"), and a pretty unreasonable price ($69 Cdn. out here Alberta-ways). Drop the price and raise the ABV and you've got a winner here. Which, come to think of it, is exactly what I say about everything carrying the Basil Hayden name.
Light and sweet, maybe too much so. But there's a nutty finish to this that is nice. Simplistic but let's not be snobby about it, this is decent. 10/27/17

Do you tell people about eating kale? Quinoa? Acai? Have a Beard? Perhaps a sleeve of tattoos? Worn in boots? This RYE is for you my friend (lord knows you’ve been telling people about rye for a while now anyway)- the taste is ORGANIC, chalky, dry, earthy, unsweetened chocolate, instant coffee minus the coffee flavor, unfiltered rye distillate.


I’ll stick with sazerac 🥃

$49

I honestly loved this because it was different. Doesn't smell or taste like a normal bourbon or whiskey but I don't think it was meant to. Strong sweet nose of cab and port wines.  No bite or burn at all really. Sweet and really nutty finish. All the wine drinkers that have had some at my place have really liked it. Nice to have in the collection.
An extremely strong nose of Cabernet. Very unique taste. More like cherry cola. Understandable that it’s more a port-wine than rye whiskey. Don’t hate it, but it’s different.

Ugh. Looks great, smells wonderful. First sip with ice was nice. Neat was okay for the first few sips. But port was too pronounced and did nothing for the whiskey. I could not finish. I was hopeful. Glad I had it in a bar and didn't just buy a bottle at the Jim Beam Urban Stillhouse. Disappointing.
Love this stuff!! Taste a little nutty like pecan in a way. I like it because it's different and taste really good on my palate!! Big ups!
Insanely good rye. On top of the spice from the rye, I pick up notes of blackberries and cola. Not too much on the nose. The finish is smooth.

Amber-ruby color - very striking colors brought from port. Very strong aromas of almond and vanilla through out. Rye notes up front with slight alcohol burn in the middle, finishing with the sweet nuttiness and port. Very complex dram with a distinct roasted almond flavor- great buy for price.

Not a whiskey when you’re craving whiskey.. The rye blend is dominated by the port - making for a sweet almost dessert-like experience. Pronounced dark berry and vanilla custard tones on the palate. Very low heat and minimal rye spice. Truly a unique and unexpected pour.
Heavy on the vanilla, well rounded, surprisingly sweet and amazingly delicious
I personally like this a lot. Pick up a lot of dried fruit notes. Particularly raisin.
Completely different than anything before. If you’re craving straight rye, go else where but this was really pleasant. The port comes through with dried fruit notes.

If you are a whiskey purist..DON’T BUY!  The port will ruin it for you. But I found it interesting and unique. Sweet, smooth, chocolate, vanilla, with sweet wood tannins. On the nose I do get rye notes. Good for after dinner. This one could be enjoyed by those who say they don’t like whiskey.
It's not bad, but doesn't really taste like a rye. Good dessert drink.
This is amazing! I can drink this all day everyday.

Easily one of my favorite whiskies to date. A blended rye influenced heavily with Kentucky rye, followed by Canadian rye from their Alberta distillery, and then blended with a touch of California port. Smells exactly like a wine bottle when you open it up, which I found very interesting, and goes down like silk with those port notes and sweet fruity undertones, with a slight variation of a classic rye finish. Well worth the price and adventure to try a one if a kind whiskey.

Completely dominated by the port. Very smooth and gentle but the port taste on the finish completely overwhelms and ruins the experience to the point it barely tastes like whiskey anymore. I tried to use it in a cocktail just to get through the bottle and the port still cut through it all.

I didn't like this at all, at first. But I took a different approach...this isn't bourbon. It tastes more like wine, with a hint of bourbon. If you know what you are expecting, the latter half of the bottle was actually enjoyable.

Not very good. Strange weird blend of flavors. I mix it with coke, terrible on the rocks. One of the worst whiskeys I have personally ever sipped. Way over priced at $50. At $25 it would earn another star.
One of my favorite whiskeys. So much flavor!

To me, this tastes like a premixed Manhattan. Of course, the sweet vermouth has been substituted with port, but the taste is very similar. I added  about a third of Wiser's 15, which is predominately corn, to cut down on the  port sweetness. This produces a lovely cocktail.
Raleigh trip with my baby June, 2018. First sip was intriguing. After that, it was like an extra sugary, thick, fruit cocktail. Seriously almost avoided finishing my double.
Tried in an OF. Slight burn but sweet aftertaste.
It’s not bad at all. Not awesome but about 3.5 stars.
When her face routine excites u.
could just be how much I love port, but this really speaks to me. very sweet, very nutty
Sweeter than I expected, but pleasant. Significant briny aftertaste.

Like most Basil Hayden's, it's very light on the palate. This dark rye is quite sweet, even for BH. Little to no bite, so you can down a glass of this very fast... or make it disappear into a mixed drink. Good for a common drink, but you'll be looking for far better if you want something to savor.

Not whiskey to me more wine in taste. I like the suggestion of using for Sangria that may actually work. For me though was a waste of money I could have bought a good bottle for much less. Or just regular Basil Hayden’s which I truly enjoy
A complete surprise when I first tasted it. Rye heat, but sweet with a very apparent nutty finish. Waited 6 months to find it again.
The port just over powers anything good about this.
Caramel apple, port wine, slight bite at the end.
Unusual and interesting. It’s good. But, probably not a regular “go to” whiskey.
Sweet back - slow burn - dull front

1.75/5

This was a bad idea from the start. Rye flavors in the cheeks and teeth, and raisins on the tougue. Permanent... Really?
jam, syrup, ripe plums, port notes are very prominent and overpower rye spice.
An interesting twist in a Manhattan
Harsh, spicy, dark. Sort of what I expected, but not a rye guy
Honestly just kinda tastes like butt
The more I've had the less I like. skip

Great cold weather sipper. Spectacular value. The port is very evident so it might no be for everyone. Extremely smooth... with its low abv, a very dangerous easy sipper. One of my go to for entertaining guests.
Liked it, loved the colour, but couldn't avoid the taste of port simply being added to the mash.
Smooth, velvety mouthfeel with plum and dark fruits dominating.  The rye spiciest you would expect is mild and does help mellow the sweetness of the whiskey.  Overall, it is good but unremarkable.
Awful finish, tastes like something rotten or sour. The initial sip was nice, but I can't get past that finish.
Wow...it's so offputting and awful. Jesus this is bad. Do not buy.
Very unique taste. Sweet and smooth but has a strong rye taste.
Dark color, cinnamony nose. Very sweet syrupy
Whole this is quite basic- I really enjoy this. Had at Dwight Olson’s house in South Carolina
Very sweet, almost too fruity. Short finish and almost syrupy feel. Would do well in cocktails
Port on the nose and definitely port n the finish. In the middle... I guess I can taste the whiskey here, but I’m trying too hard. If the port was dialed way back I think I’d appreciate it more.
Different than any rye I’ve ever had, port definitely takes over but like the uniqueness.  Will be a good nightcap/ desert drink.  Smooth- Don’t expect anything comparable to other rye whiskeys.
This whiskey was very disappointing. Odd, syrupy flavor, not pleasant.
Smells like butter and wine. Tastes like low fat no sodium butter and cheap wine. Needless to say, I cannot believe that it is not butter. Will not purchase again.

Dark reddish brown in color. 
I’m smelling wine and clay on the nose with a little bit of corn fighting for attention in the background. 
Sweet sangria, clay and oak fill out the palate with some mild spice coming in right at the end. The faintest of burns coats the back of your throat on the way down.
The mouthfeel is medium.
I suppose I enjoy this (now) a bit more than I did as a “first experience”. As a newly popped bottle, this drank more like grape Play-Doh than anything else. I even returned the second bottle I had purchased out of shear disappointment.
Now, at the end of the bottle (my wife obviously likes it), I can say it’s at least drinkable. While, as a bit of a purist, I don’t really approve of the addition of actual wine to the blend...it’s a nice, sweet after-dinner sipper. 3.65.
Best in an Old Fashioned. Just the right amount of sweetness.
dark sticky fruit in a wet rye field enjoyed best neat at room temp
Very spicy and has a great bite but a subtle sweetness that makes it very drinkable.
Very sweet, very port forward flavor, can't even tell this is rye. Very disappointing, was hoping for a rye.
Delicious rye with a sweet finish.  not rough, but a smooth finish ending on the sweet side.
I understand aging in port barrels.I don’t understand simply mixing whiskey with port as it looks and tastes  like it was done here.  Too similar to wine for me to repeat purchase.
Fantastic. Sweet caramely buttery spicy rye. Love this style.
Easy to drink but too fruity for a real rye, I used it as a cocktail and it works well with Campari and orange bitters.
Definitely on the sweeter side, but a nice way to enjoy the port finish with the spice and bite of rye to support it.

Port dominated this bottle and hid the traditional whiskey flavors I look for. Rye spice was only a suttle hint at the end that led to a wierd musty finish. May be enteresting to share with friends that mainly drink wine. I wont personaly be picking this up again.
Excellent after dinner sipper. Very smooth and chocolate fruit and port notes dash of grassy ness would have with a cigar not as sweet as forty creek unity forty creek Portwood destroyed it 😉

On the nose, ripe red fruits, sugar, maple syrup and a slight spiced yeast aroma. On the palate, sweet and fruity. More Port than Rye. The wine takes over upon the first taste. Super desserty, easy drinking and smooth.

On the Nose
Oak
Plum
Cherry
Honey
Salted caramels 

Taste
Hard cherry candies 
Plum
Honey
Barrel

Not sure if I really liked this one too much. It’s a smooth drinker and as many other reviewers said, it’s sweet. Not sickly candy sweet but definitely sweeter than I would like a rye whiskey to be. Overall it’s a nice after dinner drink or even with a nice Connecticut cigar it would compliment well. Just not my everyday go to rye especially at $40/bottle.
Sweet, smooth, lots of caramel up front.
Very smooth with a Carmel finish!!!
The more I drink other ryes, the less I think I like this.  It is really sweet, and I feel more port than rye.  I can see this as a desert drink or in some cocktails.
Fairly mild and the port sweetness is different. Would make for a good after dinner drink.
The bartender warned me it was sweeter than I’d expect. He was right! The taste was delectable but the added port definitely gave it a sweeter flavor.
Didn't like the smell, smooth and great taste
Wine soaked ripe fruits, vanilla, spice, quite distinctive port-wine on the palate

Simple drinking rye with a sweet port finish. Discontinued at the LCBO..$16 off!  

Great for cocktails and low proof guests that want to pretend they can drink rye neat.
Delicious red table wine, plums, prunes, and berries, with a slight hint of rye on the nose, red blend wine with rye, vanilla and toffee on the palate, finish is short, sweet and pleasant.
Delicious! Very smooth, sweet, tastes of caramel and dark berry fruit. Very good.
Could not finish. I tried. Overpowering taste of overly ripe almost rotten grapes upon swallow.
Appropriately rated at a 78. It’s weird. Not a normal rye by any means. I get that they were trying to do something unique but it doesn’t work for me.

The nose is mostly ripe fruits; plums and slightly sour cherries, with touches of oak and vanilla behind it. The palate is very smooth with the fruit carrying over softly, while vanilla, dry wine and a hint of cinnamon round out the palate. The finish is short with fading ripe fruit.
A bit too sweet without the spice kick I like

If you want a real rye I recommend you buy a real rye. If you want a strange curiosity that doesn't really resemble rye that much, give this a try. Sometimes I find the port off-putting, sometimes I find this quite tasty. I prefer it straight, as I haven't found a cocktail I think it works really well in, but I still have half a bottle to work with...
Smooth dark caramel, vanilla, and oak.
tastes too much like port. I'll be using this in old fashioneds. not very enjoyable straight up.
Really smooth with a sweet finish
Not a big rye fan generally but very smooth. Served on rocks
Tasting at VA ABC. Plastic taster, neat.  Wine and port dominate, with jammy fruit notes and hint of vanilla.  No burn, a touch cloying.  I see what they are doing here, but not a fan.  6/21/19
Pairs really good with BBQ pork.
Should be served with a toothbrush...points for creativity, but another disappointing BH swing and a miss.
Decent aftertaste, smooth and sweet.   Very butterscotchy

If you like rye and enjoy some funky things this is for you. The port wine added to it gives it a nice sweetness and covers up any abrasiveness. Very dark liquid because of this but easy drinking and a favorite go to
Mild. Refreshing with a slightly oversweet finish
Not my favorite but the port addition makes it interesting
Spice .. wood ..smoke and a slightly sweet finish. Almost an instant old fashioned.
Interesting with Port wine character to balance rye blend
Very smooth at 80-proof, a little sweeter than I expected- fantastic dessert sipping!

I am a big fan of Basil Hayden’s Bourbon, and have both the Caribbean Reserve and Dark Ryes. This blend of American and Canadian Ryes with Port is very tasty. The fruitiness of the Port blends well with the Rye spice. It is sweet, but not nearly as sweet as the Caribbean Reserve.
Bartender recommended. Little too sweet for me due to the wine addition. But not bad.
This was one of my favorites. Smooth, a tiny bit of smoke, sweet port after taste. Delicious
A bit flat, one dimensional, not complex. Short finish. Like stale rye bread. Almost a little dank
Rich almost bourbon. Great smooth taste
Cut the Antica back to a half oz, add the usual bitters and this makes a lovely Manhattan. A real Maraschino is a must of course.
I like this. Not complex but drinks real easy. Think brown sugar on rye bread.  Shorter finish as you would expect for the proof. Nice dessert pour.
I really like this one. Full bodied with notes of caramel and vanilla.

Upon organizing a small 'finished rye' tasting I realized I wouldn't make it to Kentucky to pick up my rye of choice, so pinch hitting for Woodfords Wine Cask  finished rye today is non other than Basil Haydens Dark(port added) Rye.  The other contenders, Angels Envy Rum Finished,  High Wests Midwinter Act 7 (port finished), (we had a no show for James Pepper).   

So how did the pedestrian Basil Hayden match up to these heavy hitters?  Choice by nose complexity, character and quality.

1 Basil Hayden
2 Angels Envy
3 Midwinters

By taste: 

Tie: Angels Envy - Basil Hayden
3rd Midwinters

The group agreed that the overall sweetness and rich character added by Basils port matched up to Rum factor in the Angels with the later winning in the "sweet" category while the Basils had just a bit more character in deep richness.   Midwinters came in last as the finish was mild to subdued and  really just notable.

In over all value the relative msrp's  again found Basil just edging out the much higher priced Angels while the Midwinters again lagged.   Overall  rich rye's,  hot chilli and good cigars were consumed in good spirits for what went over as a good head to head taste off and somewhat surprisingly little Basil punched well over it's weight to take the event.   We all were somewhat amazed the Basil Hayden could deliver at that level, esp with a pair like the Angels Envy and Midwinters in the house.  For me the richness of the port addition made it an easy winner and if the "finish" technique is of questionable fairness in comparison at the end of the day it's the taste that counts.   With the Angels Envy being about 10 dollars more than the High West, it was a unanimous 2nd in value and nose to nose in quality of drink with Basils.  That alone is some serious recommendation for what Basil Hayden is doing with it's dark rye addition.   Rye drinkers who desire a real change up in sweet richness should give serious consideration to this dark and spicy blend.
Fruity and vanilla nose. Warm. Tart with a vanilla taste.

Let's start by saying this is a nice drink on the rocks. It is more of a cocktail in a bottle than a straight whiskey so all of the negativee comments can pound sand. 

What it isn't - a top shelf straight drinker.

What it is - a lovely port and whiskey blend that does fantastic over a few cubes. My reccomendation is that you have a healthy pour over ice and ignore the naysayers!

Dark dark dark. 
Chocolate 
Carmel 
Spice
It's just ok. Wouldn't go back to it
Caramelized flavour, notes of toffee and dried fruit with oak spice and a hint of port in the finish.
A smooth, and sweet rye bourbon with a notes of spice and vanilla.

If your expecting a straight whiskey finished your right. If you're expecting this to taste like whiskey you're wrong. 

To be blunt this is great as finished whiskey, but far from good straight whiskey.

A great whiskey full of dark fruits and a light nuttiness. Great for a Manhattan or someone looking to drink something heavily finished. 

I sub this for vermouth in Manhattans and have blended it with their rum finish to make a great cocktail.
Very tasty not has high on the vanilla as the expert says

Waiting for take out I decided to grab a pour of this one... What's unique about this one is it's a blend of their rye with Canadian Whiskey and Port (added not finished in a port barrel). Like all Basil Haden products it's bottled at 40% ABV. Let's dive in:

On the palette it's thick, sweet and syrupy. Lots of candied berry notes that lean towards artificial tasting. Some spice shows itself on the mid palette with a bit of oak on the short finish. It's definitely very sweet. This is an after dinner dram for those with a sweet tooth. 

My personal preference is to avoid anything that has artificial sweet notes and on this one I get those notes. So it's a pass for me. For those who are fans of syrupy and sweet Whiskey try before you buy! 

Cheers all!

Tried at a bar in a rocks glass

Nose: Oak spice, and that sweet port 

Palate: A toasty rye bread, a subtle dry oak, followed by a lengthy molasses and black tea finish.

Final impression: i have never really been of basil hayden, but the rye has me questioning my taste of this Jim Beam small batch line. I would recommend this to a rye fan that is looking for something a little different

Decent “whiskey”. I think the expert’s comment that this whiskey is “one-dimensional” is accurate. The port imparts some nice flavor (if you enjoy port), but it just feels flat in your mouth. I’m reminded of Angel’s Envy Bourbon, finished in Port Barrels. You can definitely taste the port in that whiskey, but the flavors are deep and subtle. 

The Basil Hayden’s just tastes like Rye whiskey mixed with Port wine. Like I could mix up a new bottle in my kitchen. I guess that’s what it really is, but it’d probably be 4 stars for me if it was blended and then finished in a port barrel. Then again, it’d probably be $50+ instead of $35. You get what you pay for sometimes.
Port is up front and it tastes light

I've had only one drink of this at a bar, 2 oz. ...so it's hard to judge. But what I do distinctly remember was that it was sweet, tart, and fruity... then after a bit, there was some odd soy saucy aftertaste. It wasn't terrible...just unexpected...and weird.
Goes down way smooth. Maybe too sweet?
Cherries and burnt vanilla on the nose.  Stone fruit and cherries are upfront on the palate that gives way to vanilla and bread notes.  Next is pepper and a Classic strong rye finish.

Color is dark golden red. Legs are notably quick moving. Nose has obvious hints of red wine with rye spiciness and sweet vanilla underneath. Palate surprisingly switches to vanilla and fruit dominant with the red wine and rye flavors more as undertones. Finish is medium, smooth, and sweet. A unique whiskey that I would recommend for wine lovers.

Nose: Like waving your hand toward your nose to smell a freshly popped jar of prunes, plums, pommagranite and cherry jam. Afternotes of vanilla, dark chocolate and mild coffee grinds. 

Pallette: Mild intro to vanilla with a pop of sweet port wine. The taste comes and goes quickly with a short after flavor of cherries. Very subtle alcohol.

General: Sadly it lacks the spice of a true rye. Very much a whiskey version of port wine that would work well with desserts and possibly cigars.
Outstanding taste - love the port taste.
Very sippable … smooth, warms your soul. Vanilla, wood, a little heat, the port adds a lovely touch. Great mouth feel.
Sweet, cherry vanilla notes. Not like most eyes. Not peaty. Kind of rich.

I had been looking at this bottle in my grocery for a while. Price dropped to $28, so I snagged it. 
Not knowing what to expect.... I dove in. 
The nose is sweet, with the definite hints of vanilla. The subtle rye spice hits as well. The palate is where it gets a bit interesting. The port comes through with its sweetness immediately. You get some oak and leather tones.... as well as dark fruits. It’s very palatable. It reminds me of something... and on the second taste, I place it. This literally reminds me of drinking a Manhattan. As you taste it, imagine it with a Luxardo cherry. The oil is there, and lingers on the aftertaste.
I was pleasantly surprised with this pour. I will be keeping this stocked for a while
Expected more, it’s smooth but a bit bland.
Just not my thing. Glad I got to try a sample of it though.

Nose: egg nog, nutmeg, licorice

Palate: thick, artificially oily, nutmeg and anisette 

Finish: a bit spicy and oily

Aroma is black licorice and candi sugar. Syrupy sweetness, very thick palate. The red wine seeps in just a bit. Cherrywood and mahogany. Spicy resinous flavors. I am really enjoying this with one small ice cube.
Light on the palate, not fiery. Definite port flavor on the back end.
Disgustingly sweet from the port they add. Yuck.
Unbelievably drinkable. Almost like white dog
I liked the first sip and it’s growing on me more and more. Someone mentioned it’s like a Manhattan, and I agree. I got it on sale and it’s good for the price.
I thought it was great. Full body, rich, sweet, spicy. Lots going on. Much better than the Basil Hayden’s bourbon.

Just plain bad. Sweet with a gross port flavor that’s isn’t subtle like you might get if it was aged in port barrels. Some idiot distiller thought it was a good idea to just dump port into the whiskey. How wrong he was

Unique. Immediately upon opening I get port wine notes. Fig, cherry pie filling, plums. Palate brings more of the same and some spanish cedar and white pepper.

As a big fan of port wine, I'm glad this is a regular in their line. Sweetness from the Canadian wine make it almost too much. But with ice I think this will make a great sipper and  cut the sweetness a bit.
Very sweet. More like pre-mixed cocktail. Not great.

Enjoyed neat from a rocks glass at a restaurant.  This is going to be a short review.

This is sweet (ish), fruity (ish), cloying, and mostly inoffensive.  It is not, however, a rye.  There's nothing rye-like to speak of. There's very little to the (short) finish. No spices. No crazy fruitcake notes. No pepper.  No complexity.  No spark.

What is there?

Whatever it was bored the bejesus out of me.  Pour an indifferent port into a indifferent rye and you'll end up with something like this. 

I don't like it and I'm certainly not spending money to buy a bottle after this tasting. I can think of  half a dozen other whiskies I'd rather have, and all priced under $20 per bottle.

This is a rye for people who don't like rye... or  whiskey.

Hard pass
Starts with the port and ends with the rye spice. Very mild flavor, easy to drink.

This rye smells amazing but taster too much like wine to me. 
Nose - I get plums and brown sugar right away, then a sour mustiness comes though. Way in the background a get a touch of rye spice. 
Taste - Big brown sugar sweetness mixed with some rye spice on the first sip. The port and sour notes round things out. 
Finish - The sour port flavors linger for awhile, with a touch if rye spice. Probably my least favorite part of the experience.
Simple, but love the spice and wine flavor.
Too bland.  Lacks any spicy bite of a rye
Not a typical rye,  I was skeptical about sherry with the rye and was amazingly surprised.  All flavors noted in a smooth drink.  I drank it neat and will try a splash or cube next time.
Dark and smooth, sweet for a rye with maple flavors
Weird flavor, almost like a bad wine
Apple, cinnamon, citrus and cherry. Syrupy body, smooth and balanced. Nearly a pre-made old fashioned.

This interesting treat is a dark pigskin leather brown. And very thin oily legs dribble down the glass.

The nose is quite fruity. There are notes of grape skins, cherry, vanilla, brown sugar, maple syrup, bread yeast, cinnamon, and a reminiscent scent of a craft store.

The palate is watery, and notes of red wine, plum, dark chocolate covered cherries, and waxy pecan and cashew meld together. It’s a Christmasy flavor that is really unique.

The shorter finish ends not unpleasantly peppery and fruity.

This rye threw me off at first when a buddy served me a glass, and I thought was strange until I read up on what it was. With the addition of port wine it really adds a dominant fruity layer, making it a whiskey I believe a wine lover would enjoy. Also the notes bespeak the holidays, so thoughI wouldn’t want it all the time, I may just buy a bottle come Christmas! Beam, thanks for the interesting dram. Cheers!
Not the 1st taste, but 2&3, way smoother

A very interesting whiskey, a blend of two rye whiskies and a cask finish in californian port wood gives this dram a strange palette of flavors, some that i have never had before in a dram. 

Bottled at 40%abv, Chesnut color, very red.

On the nose: Rye upfront. Cherries, Red fruits and strawberry Jam.

On the palate: here things get crazy. Starts sour. Normal Syrup. Sweet and sour. Then gets Yeasty. Sugary and prunes. Very rare flavor. Not bad. Not amazing though. 

Aftertaste has notes of prunes and lemoncello. 

Overall this is a very interesting maybe awkward dram, to drink it neat is quite the experience, but i am sure this makes great cocktails. 78 over 100.

Very different rye... so much that it doesn’t taste like one.  Somewhat oily but not necessarily in a bad way.  Can taste the fruity/wine hits from the port aging.  Russell got for me from Coast Guard shop.

A really nice “change of pace” specialty whiskey. Sweet fruit notes and enough of a spicy note to balance out. Flavor is rich, but not intense or long lived. The port wine essence is there without covering up the rye flavor.
Mildly spicy, moves into a mellow sweet
Wonderful rye with a pinch of sweetness.
Can’t taste the rye at all. Very sweet. Blended with port, not finished. Buyer beware.
Very good, smooth red wine finish to it.

Nose:  sweet fruity (plum and cherry), oaky, chicory, peppery but more like green peppercorn not just black pepper, (buttery maybe?). 

Taste: sweet sherry/wine up front with the plum being the primary fruit flavor, nutmeg, cinnamon, vanilla, oaky tannin, as it fades the oak becomes more pronounced and the spices really take off, pepper comes on at the end and oddly a sort of cola-type flavor without the saccharine sweetness of drinking soda, but it works really well with the rest of the flavors so not at all unpleasant.

Was kind of disappointed with this one. I’m a fan of the standard BH and I’ve had the Alberta Rye this was blended with and it was really nice too. Together they made a whiskey that I found to be disjointed. I wouldn’t get it again.
Very smooth, lots of dried fruit, lingering, spicy, finish. Wish the ABV was a little higher.

Nose: brown sugar, baking spices, dried dark fruits, cherries, orange peel, wood, vanilla
Palette: cinnamon, allspice, black pepper, wood tannins, cherries, dried cranberries, peppermint?, Yeasty bread
Finish: baking spices, warm vanilla, dark dried fruits, brown sugar

This is a Christmas fruitcake in a glass.
Strong fruity taste.   Does lack the strong Rye spice of other Rye whiskies.  Good if you like whiskies heavily influenced by port or sherry caks.  Tasted neat.
Smooth, dry port flavors.  Thicker mouth feel.  Love it
This tastes like a Brandy. So fruity kinda over powers any spiceness from the rye. Highly drinkable at 40%. Looking for a nice Brandy take it. Looking for a rye look elsewhere.
Dark amber/ruby color, light spice nose, soft vanilla and citrus taste, little afterburn, as smooth as a nice bourbon.
Vanilla and spicy with a smooth finish. Not a full-mouth flavor. Hits the tip and back sides of the tongue
